revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contributions/162.233.48.106|162.233.48.106]] ([[User talk:162.233.48.106|talk]]): addition of [[WP:BLP|unsourced content]] to a biographical article ([[WP:HG|HG]]) (3.4.4)
revision.text:
{{about|the comedian and actor|the marine biologist|Christopher D'Elia}} {{Infobox person | name = Chris D'Elia | image = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1980|3|29}} | birth_place = [[Montclair, New Jersey]], U.S.{{cite web|last=O'Brien|first=Conan|title=Chris D'Elia Loves Mocking British Tough-Guys|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rRgAJKN0VNk|work=[[Conan (talk show)|Conan on TBS]]|publisher=YouTube|accessdate=4 August 2013}} | residence = [[Beachwood Canyon, Los Angeles, California]] | alias = | occupation = {{Flatlist | *Comedian *actor *podcaster *writer}} | education = [[La Cañada High School]] | years_active = 1996–present | spouse = {{marriage|Emily Montague|2006|2010}} | parents = [[Bill D'Elia]]
Ellie D'Elia | relatives = Matt D'Elia (brother) | website = {{URL|chrisdelia.com}} }} '''Christopher D'Elia''' (born March 29, 1980) is an [[Americans|American]] [[Stand up comedian|stand-up comedian]], actor, writer and podcast host. He is known for playing Alex Miller on the [[NBC]] sitcom ''[[Whitney (TV series)|Whitney]]''; Danny Burton on the sitcom ''[[Undateable]]'', also on NBC; and Kenny on ''[[The Good Doctor (TV series)|The Good Doctor]]'' on [[American Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]]. ==Early life== D'Elia was born in New Jersey, the son of TV producer and director [[Bill D'Elia]],{{cite web|last1=Tomashoff|first1=Craig|title=Like Father, Like Son|url=http://stephenschofield.files.wordpress.com/2013/03/delias.jpg|website=Emmy|accessdate=20 July 2014|year=March 2013}} and interior decorator Ellie D'Elia (née Dombroski). He has a younger brother, filmmaker/actor Matt D'Elia. His father is first generation Italian-American.{{cite web|last1=Martin|first1=Babara E.|title=Bill D' Elia: Hollywood Storyteller|url=http://ww2.wpunj.edu/adminsrv/pub-info/billhollywood.htm|website=WP: The Magazine of William Paterson University|accessdate=July 18, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20011230112149/http://ww2.wpunj.edu/adminsrv/pub-info/billhollywood.htm|archivedate=30 December 2001|date=Winter 2001}} He was raised in [[Montclair, New Jersey]] until age twelve, when his family relocated to [[Los Angeles, California]].{{cite web|last1=Downs|first1=Gordon|title=Interview With Comedian Chris D'Elia|url=http://www.sandiego.com/articles/2011-01-19/interview-comedian-chris-delia|website=San Diego|accessdate=July 18, 2014|date=January 19, 2011}} He graduated from [[La Cañada High School]] in 1998.{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/socal/la-canada-valley-sun/community/tn-vsl-me-102030-20170522-story.html|work=The Los Angeles Times|title=La Cañada History: Comedian Chris D'Elia has role in LCHS production of ‘The Pajama Game’|date=May 22, 2017|accessdate=June 28, 2017|author=Cormaci, Carol}} ==Career== D'Elia started acting in high school, and had some guest starring parts on ''[[Chicago Hope]].''{{cite web|last1=Gleib|first1=Ben|title=#034: Guest Chris D'Elia: "God Particle Testicle Fish"|url=http://smodcast.com/episodes/guest-chris-delia-god-particle-testicle-fish|website=Last Week on Earth with Ben Gleib|publisher=[[Smodcast]]|accessdate=August 15, 2014|format=Audio interview/podcast|date=July 11, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150427111131/http://smodcast.com/episodes/guest-chris-delia-god-particle-testicle-fish/|archivedate=April 27, 2015}} He attended [[New York University]] and studied acting but dropped out after a year because he didn't like college. He then appeared in a movie that went straight to DVD. During his downtime as an actor he started writing scripts. When he was 25 he decided to do standup, which he had always wanted to do.{{cite web|last1=Lamoray|first1=Lena|title=Exclusive Interview Chris D’Elia, Chris plays STANKOWSKI in GLORY DAZE on TBS|url=http://www.lenalamoray.com/2011/02/02/exclusive-interview-chris-delia-chris-plays-stankowski-in-glory-daze-on-tbs/|website=Lena Lamoray|accessdate=July 20, 2014|date=February 2, 2011}} D'Elia has been doing stand-up comedy since 2006. He considers himself to be a standup comedian who acts. He has been featured on [[Comedy Central]]'s ''[[Live at Gotham]]'', ''[[Comedy Central Presents]]'', and [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]]'s ''Live Nude Comedy''. He was introduced to a broader audience as a regular on the series ''[[Glory Daze (TV series)|Glory Daze]]'',{{cite news|last1=Wiegand|first1=David|title='Whitney' review: Too much stand-up in sitcom|url=http://www.sfchronicle.com/tv/article/Whitney-review-Too-much-stand-up-in-sitcom-2309219.php|accessdate=July 20, 2014|work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]|page=E1|date=21 September 2011}} which ran for one season on [[TBS (U.S. TV channel)|TBS]], playing "the Oracle", William Stankowski. He was originally only cast for the pilot, but was made a series regular. He co-starred in the [[NBC]] comedy series ''[[Whitney (TV series)|Whitney]]'', opposite comedian [[Whitney Cummings]], for two seasons.{{cite web|last1=Clements|first1=Erin|title=Whitney Cummings, Chris D'Elia Talk Dating Deal-Breakers, Go-To Excuses For HuffPost's #nofilter|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/11/15/whitney-cummings-chris-delia-no-filter_n_2131916.html|website=[[Huffington Post]]|accessdate=July 20, 2014|date=November 15, 2012}} D'Elia was one of three hosts of the ''Ten Minute Podcast'' (from 2012 to 2015), along with [[Bryan Callen]] and [[Will Sasso]]. Since February 2017, he has hosted the weekly podcast ''Congratulations with Chris D'Elia'', which has charted in the top 20 comedy podcasts in multiple countries.{{citation needed|date=March 2018}} Other podcasts have been heavily influenced by his style, including ''The Fighter and the Kid'', hosted by friend [[Bryan Callen]] and former MMA fighter turned [[E!]] host [[Brendan Schaub]].{{Citation|last=The Fighter and The Kid|title=The Fighter and The Kid - Episode 265: Chris D'Elia|date=2017-06-05|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KfeCYPWyj7s|accessdate=2018-03-24}} D'Elia also gained over 2 million followers on [[Vine (service)|Vine]]. In January 2013, D'Elia released his debut parody rap album, as MC "Chank Smith", called ''Such Is Life'' (produced by [[Mr. Green (record producer)|Mr. Green]]).{{cite news|last1=Gutierrez|first1=Juan|title=Chris D'Elia's Loveably Clueless Rap Persona|url=http://www.laweekly.com/westcoastsound/2013/09/12/chris-delias-loveably-clueless-rap-persona|accessdate=July 20, 2014|work=[[LA Weekly]]|date=September 12, 2013}} On December 6, 2013, D'Elia's first one-hour stand-up special, ''White Male Black Comic'', aired on Comedy Central.{{cite web|last1=Ortiz|first1=Jen|title=The GQ+A: Comedian Chris D'Elia on His Comedy Central Special and Getting Heckled by Drunk Girls|url=https://www.gq.com/blogs/the-feed/2013/12/the-gqa-comedian-chris-delia-on-his-comedy-central-special-and-getting-heckled-by-drunk-girls.html|website=[[GQ]]|accessdate=July 20, 2014|date=December 2, 2013}} It was directed by his father. In May 2014, D'Elia was cast in the lead role of the NBC sitcom ''[[Undateable]]'', which premiered on May 29, 2014,{{cite web|last=Kasperowicz|first=Leslie|url=http://www.cinemablend.com/television/Whitney-Chris-Elia-Joins-NBC-Undateable-Pilot-53445.html|title=Whitney's Chris D'Elia Joins NBC's Undateable Pilot|work=Cinemablend|accessdate=March 4, 2014|date=March 3, 2013}} executive produced by [[Bill Lawrence (TV producer)|Bill Lawrence]].{{cite news|last1=Stanley|first1=Alessandra|title=A Bunch of Friends? Yeah, Again: ‘Undateable’ Keeps a Sitcom Formula Alive|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/05/29/arts/television/undateable-keeps-a-sitcom-formula-alive.html?_r=0|accessdate=July 18, 2014|work=[[New York Times]]|date=May 28, 2014}} The show is a multi-camera sitcom with a live audience,{{cite web|last1=Steinberg|first1=Lisa|title=Interviews – TV: Chris D'Elia & Bill Lawrence – Undateable|url=http://starrymag.com/?p=3165|website=Starry Constellation Magazine|accessdate=July 20, 2014|date=May 23, 2014}} based on the book ''Undateable: 311 Things Guys Do That Guarantee They Won't Be Dating or Having Sex'' by Ellen Rakieten and Anne Coyle.{{cite web|last1=Goldberg|first1=Lesley|title=NBC's Bill Lawrence Comedy 'Undateable' Casts Lead |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/nbcs-bill-lawrence-comedy-undateable-422689|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|accessdate=July 18, 2014|date=February 20, 2013}} The show often incorporates improv, with D'Elia playing Oscar to [[Brent Morin]]'s straight-man Felix à la ''[[The Odd Couple (1970 TV series)|The Odd Couple]].'' The cast includes stand-up comics who were good friends before the show.{{cite web|last1=Ray|first1=Lincee|title=5 reasons to watch 'Undateable'|url=http://community.ew.com/2014/06/19/five-reasons-to-watch-undateable|website=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|accessdate=July 18, 2014|date=June 19, 2014}}{{cite web|last1=Radish|first1=Christina|title=Brent Morin Talks 'Undateable,' Performing Stand-Up, His Weird Life Journey with Chris D’Elia, Being Funny on Camera, Singing on the Show, and More|url=http://collider.com/brent-morin-undateable-interview/|publisher=[[Collider (website)|Collider]]|accessdate=July 18, 2014|date=July 6, 2014}}{{cite web|last1=King|first1=Larry|title=The Cast of "Undateable"|url=http://www.ora.tv/larrykingnow/the-cast-of-undateable-0_3yambvfisshv|website=Larry King Now|accessdate=26 July 2014|date=June 11, 2014}} In 2015, Bill Lawrence and the cast (D'Elia, Brent Morin, Ron Funches, and Rick Glassman) went on a series of stand-up tour dates to promote the show.{{cite web|last1=Littleton|first1=Cynthia|title=Bill Lawrence and 'Undateable' Stars Hit the Road to Promote NBC Comedy 'Undateable'|url=https://variety.com/2014/tv/news/bill-lawrence-and-undateable-stars-hit-the-road-to-promote-nbc-comedy-undateable-1201120161/|website=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|accessdate=July 18, 2014|date=February 25, 2014}}{{cite web|last1=Lawrence|first1=Bill|title=The ‘Undateable’ Comedy Tour: How to Launch (or Not Launch) a TV Show in 2014|url=http://grantland.com/hollywood-prospectus/the-undateable-comedy-tour-how-to-launch-or-not-launch-a-tv-show-in-2014|website=[[Grantland]]|accessdate=July 18, 2014|date=May 28, 2014}} In 2016, D'Elia headlined the Leafly 420 Comedy Tour show in Chicago with special guest Ron Funches.{{Cite web|url=https://events.leafly.com/events/leafly-comedy-tour-chicago/?_ga=1.230673301.828060596.1451429102|title=Leafly Comedy Tour Chicago|website=Leafly Events|access-date=2016-04-23}} D'Elia has developed a significant fanbase. He jokingly calls this following his "cult".{{Cite news|url=https://twitter.com/chrisdelia/status/772678653746434048?lang=en|title=Chris D'elia Tweet about starting cult|last=|first=|date=|work=Twitter|access-date=2018-03-24|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}} ==Personal life== D'Elia was raised Catholic. In a standup routine, he joked about how creepy certain aspects of Catholic mass are.{{when|date=January 2013}} In 2006, D'Elia married actress Emily Montague. They divorced in 2010.{{citation needed|date=February 2018}} Despite the fact that his characters in ''Whitney'' (Alex Miller) and ''Undateable'' (Danny Burton) are both portrayed as frequent drinkers, D'Elia has never used drugs or alcohol.{{cite web|last1=Roots|first1=Kimberly|title=Whitney Season 2 Preview: Whitney Cummings on Alex's Issues, the Possible Patter of Little Feet|url=http://tvline.com/2012/11/12/whitney-season-2-spoilers-whitney-cummings-kids|website=[[TV Line]]|accessdate=July 20, 2014|date=November 12, 2012}} At the Chicago Leafly 420 show, D'Elia told the audience that he does not use cannabis. D'Elia lives in the [[Beachwood Canyon, Los Angeles|Beachwood Canyon]] area of Los Angeles.{{cite news|last1=David|first1=Mark|title=Comedian Craig Ferguson Sells to Comic Chris D'Elia|url=https://variety.com/2013/dirt/real-estalker/comedian-craig-ferguson-sells-to-comic-chris-delia-1201236319/|accessdate=August 15, 2014|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=August 8, 2013}} During an episode of ''[[The Joe Rogan Experience]]'', he confirmed that he frequently uses a walking aid called "rollator" when shopping. He tries to work against the stigma that old people carry. "I try to make the use of Rollators okay for the young ones. Not great, just okay. Old people matter," he told the bewildered Rogan.{{Citation|last=PowerfulJRE|title=Joe Rogan Experience #533 - Chris D'Elia|date=2014-08-11|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t930gQuODIo|accessdate=2017-03-20}} ==Influences== D'Elia has cited [[Bryan Callen]], [[Eddie Murphy]], and [[Jim Carrey]]{{cite web|last1=King|first1=Larry|title=Larry King Now: Alex Borstein & Chris D'Elia|url=http://www.ora.tv/larrykingnow/alex-borstein-chris-delia-0_ly62j85q|website=[[Larry King Now]]|accessdate=20 July 2014|date=6 December 2013}}{{cite web|title=I am comedian Chris D'Elia (from Workaholics and other things). Ask me anything. (self.IAmA)|url=https://www.reddit.com/r/IAmA/comments/1s4gm1/i_am_comedian_chris_delia_from_workaholics_and/|website=[[Reddit]]|accessdate=18 July 2014|date=5 December 2013}} as major influences on his comedic career. ==Filmography== ===Films=== {| class="wikitable sortable" ! Year ! Title ! Role ! class="unsortable" | Notes |- | 2004 | ''[[imdbtitle:0392949|Almost]]'' | Marc | |- | 2005 | ''[[Bad Girls from Valley High]]'' | Gavin | |- | 2005 | ''[[imdbtitle:0416658|Crazylove]]'' | Jake | |- | 2012 | ''[[Celeste and Jesse Forever]]'' | Snow White | |- | 2013 | ''Funny: The Documentary'' | Himself | Documentary |- | 2015 | ''[[Flock of Dudes]]'' | Adam | |- | 2016 | ''[[XOXO (2016 film)|XOXO]]''{{cite news|url=http://deadline.com/2015/07/hayley-kiyoko-of-csi-cyber-is-cast-in-xoxo-netflix-indie-fest-feature-project-1201475423/|title=Hayley Kiyoko Of ‘CSI: Cyber’ Is Cast In ‘XOXO’, Netflix’ Indie-Fest Feature Project|work=Hollywood Reporter|date=8 August 2013}} | Neil | |- | 2017 | ''[[Band Aid (film)|Band Aid]]'' | Uber Annoying | |- | 2017 | ''[[The Female Brain (film)|The Female Brain]]'' | Charlie | |- | 2017 | ''[[Little Evil]]'' | Wayne | |- | 2018 | ''[[Half Magic (film)|Half Magic]]'' | Edward | |- | 2018 | ''Life in a Year'' | Phil | |} ===Television=== {| class="wikitable sortable" ! Year ! Title ! Black Comic]]'' | Himself | Television special |- | 2013–2016 | ''[[Sanjay and Craig]]'' | Remington Tufflips | Voice; recurring role |- | 2014 | ''[[Jennifer Falls]]'' | Adam | Main role |- | 2014–2016 | ''[[Undateable]]'' | Danny Burton | Lead role |- | 2015 | ''[[Netflix|Incorrigible]]'' | Himself | Television special |- |2015 |[[Comedy Central Roast]] |Himself |Roaster - Roast of Justin Bieber |- | 2016 | ''[[Rush Hour (U.S. TV series)|Rush Hour]]'' | Buddy | Episode: "Welcome Back, Carter" |- | 2016 | ''[[Typical Rick]]'' | Lukee Sado | Episodes: "Schmooze You Lose" and "Unbroken Family" |- | 2017 | ''[[The Great Indoors (TV series)|The Great Indoors]]'' | Aaron Wolf | Episode: "Aaron Wolf" |- | 2017 | ''[[Netflix|Man On Fire]]'' | Himself | Television special |- | 2018–present | ''[[The Good Doctor (TV series)|The Good Doctor]]'' | Kenny | Recurring role |- | 2018–present | ''[[Alone Together (TV series)|Alone Together]]'' | Dean | Main role |- |} ===Web=== {| class="wikitable sortable" ! Year ! Title ! Role ! class="unsortable" | Notes |- | 2014, 2017 | ''Joe Rogan Experience'' | Himself (Special Guest) | Podcast |- | 2012–2016 | ''Ten Minute Podcast''{{Cite web|url=http://nerdist.com/last-night-on-midnight-will-sasso-bryan-callen-chris-delia/|title=Last Night On @midnight: Will Sasso, Bryan Callen, Chris D’Elia|work=[[Nerdist Podcast|Nerdist]]|date=May 30, 2011|accessdate=June 4, 2011}} | Various roles | Podcast |- | 2017–present | ''Congratulations with Chris D'Elia'' | Various roles | Podcast |- | 2018 | ''H3 Podcast'' | Himself (Special Guest) | Podcast |- |} ==Discography== ;Comedy albums {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" ! scope="col" style="width:10em;"| Title ! scope="col" style="width:16em;"| Album details |- ! scope="row" | ''Such is Life''{{Cite web|url=http://duncantrussell.com/forum/discussion/8862/chris-delia-aka-chank-smith-released-his-rap-album-such-is-life/p1|title=Chris D'elia AKA Chank Smith released his rap album...."Such is Life"|publisher=Duncan Trussell|date=30 May 2011|accessdate=4 June 2011}} | * Released: February 3, 2013 * Formats: [[Compact Disc|CD]], [[music download|digital download]] *Label: Independent |- |} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{Official website}} * {{IMDb name|0195626}} * {{Twitter|name=@chrisdelia}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:D'Elia, Chris}} [[Category:1980 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American male film actors]] [[Category:American male voice actors]] [[Category:American male comedians]] [[Category:Writers from Los Angeles]] [[Category:20th-century American male actors]] [[Category:21st-century American male actors]] [[Category:American male television actors]] [[Category:Male actors from Los Angeles]] [[Category:Male actors from New Jersey]] [[Category:American people of Italian descent]] [[Category:Male actors of Italian descent]] [[Category:Comedians from California]] [[Category:20th-century American comedians]] [[Category:21st-century American comedians]]
